ContentStructure.title: PART  1
Welcome to Part 1
Section 1.1: Academic Integrity vs. Cheating
Section 1.2: Who Owns Ideas and Information?
Section 1.3: Practice Making Good Decisions
Section 1.1 This section will answer these questions:
What is academic integrity?
How does cheating hurt the community?
How does cheating hurt an individual?
What is academic integrity?

Academic Integrity refers to the obligation of all students and faculty to be honest and responsible in all work they do. It is the expectation that they will not cheat in any aspect of their academic work.
Section 1.1

Students and faculty must produce original work, they must not copy or plagiarize, they must not take credit for the work of others, and they must not use unauthorized assistance to complete assignments and exams.
Why is cheating harmful to me?
Write your ideas in this box:
Submit
Section 1.1
Cheating harms you because...
The penalties for cheating are severe.  You could fail your class, be removed from your degree program, or even be expelled from the university.
Section 1.1
Cheating harms you because...

You’re not truly learning the academic material, which keeps you from getting what you need out of your education.   This will also hurt your future career, where you will have to use what you learned in school.
Section 1.1
Cheating harms you because...
If you think cheating once is okay, you’re more likely to cheat again in the future, both in and out of academics.  This compromises your personal moral code.
Section 1.1
Cheating harms you because...
Your reputation is damaged.  People might begin to see you as a fraud, liar, or intellectual thief.
Section 1.1
Cheating harms you because...
You don’t get to enjoy an accomplishment earned through genuine effort.
Section 1.1
Why is cheating harmful to my community?
Write your ideas in this box:
Submit
Section 1.1
Cheating harms the community because...
It creates an environment of broken trust, which makes it hard for students and faculty to work together in meaningful ways.
Section 1.1
Cheating harms the community because...
It leads to lower standards, and cheating becomes the “normal” way to compete in the school culture.  This is unfair to students who remain honest and do their own work.
Section 1.1
Cheating harms the community because...
It reduces the moral authority of school leaders, such as your professors.  It’s hard to trust a professor who allows cheating to happen and doesn’t require the same effort from all students.
Section 1.1
Cheating harms the community because...
Cheaters must depend on honest learners.   Cheaters haven’t learned or mastered their own academic work, so they rely on the efforts of other people.
Section 1.1
Cheating harms the community because...
It awards cheaters with grades, honors, and privileges that they don’t deserve.
Section 1.1

Section 1.2 This section will answer these questions:
What is scholarship as a conversation? How can I participate?
Who owns ideas and information?
How does academic culture share and use information?
Whose ideas?
Sometimes it feels like ideas belong to everyone.  On the internet, we see ideas remixed and shared all the time.
Section 1.2
Whose ideas?
In academic culture, ideas have owners. This includes information found on the internet.  You cannot claim someone else’s ideas as your own.
Section 1.2
Whose ideas?
In college, you are expected to do your own work and develop your own ideas.  If you need to mention someone else’s ideas, you must identify the true owner of those ideas.
Section 1.2
Whose ideas?
Think of it as a conversation, where each person, including you, gets to share his or her ideas.  It’s okay to discuss other people’s ideas, but you must always give them credit.
Section 1.2
Learn more. This video explains more about scholarship as a conversation.
Section 1.2
Visit this link for this video with closed captions.
You own your ideas, too.
When you write a paper, create a project, or study for an exam, your hard work belongs to you.  You should expect your classmates to put in the same effort and do their own work.
Section 1.2
An article found on the internet.
The answer key to last year’s test.
Notes that you took during class.
Your friend’s homework assignment.
A peer reviewed paper you found in a library database.
A thesis statement that you wrote.
An outline a Writing Center tutor helped you develop.
An essay from your point of view on a controversial topic.
An essay written by another student for a previous class.
The answers on your classmate’s exam.
A study guide you helped your classmates write.
A copy of the teacher’s textbook.
Answers to an online exam found on the internet.
Answers to math homework using an online problem solver.
Flashcards you made to study for an exam.
This is NOT my own effort. I CANNOT take credit for this!
This is my own effort. I can take credit for this!
Look at each example. Is it something you can claim as your own work? Drag it to the proper box at the bottom.

Section 1.3: Practice!
You will be presented with nine scenarios.  Determine if each student’s action is an example of academic integrity.  Click YES or NO to see if your answer is correct.
I made an appointment at the Writing Center to have a tutor help me with my paper.
Is this an example of academic integrity?
Section 1.3
Wrong answer.  This IS Academic Integrity.  As long as your professor approves, it’s perfectly acceptable to receive help from USA’s Writing Center. This student has done nothing wrong.
Hint: Does going to the Writing Center harm the student or his community?
Correct answer!  This IS Academic Integrity.  As long as your professor approves, it’s perfectly acceptable to receive help from USA’s Writing Center.
Hint: Does going to the Writing Center harm the student or his community?
Is this an example of academic integrity?
My cousin took this class a while back. I’ll ask if he has the answer key to the final exam.
Section 1.3

Correct answer!  This IS NOT Academic Integrity. The student isn’t learning the material. Using an old answer key cheats her of this knowledge, and it gives her an unfair advantage over students who do study.
Hint: Will using an old answer key help this student really understand the material?

Wrong answer.  This IS NOT Academic Integrity.   The student isn’t learning the material. Using an old answer key cheats her of this knowledge, and it gives her an unfair advantage over students who do study.
Hint: Will using an old answer key help this student really understand the material?
Is this an example of academic integrity?
I can’t believe I forgot to do my homework! Can I copy the answers from yours really quick before class?
Section 1.3

Correct answer!  This IS NOT Academic Integrity.   No matter how small the assignment, the student must always do her own work. If she copies the answers, she isn’t learning the information she needs for class.  It also hurts her community, because it’s unfair for her to receive credit for her friend’s effort.
Hint: Does copying homework answers hurt the student or her community?

Wrong answer.  This IS NOT Academic Integrity.   No matter how small the assignment, the student must always do her own work. If she copies the answers, she isn’t learning the information she needs for class.  It also hurts her community, because it’s unfair for her to receive credit for her friend’s effort.
Hint: Does copying homework answers hurt the student or her community?
Is this an example of academic integrity?
This topic is all over the internet. I’m just going to copy and paste one paragraph into my paper.
Section 1.3

Correct answer!  This IS NOT Academic Integrity.  The student must use his own words in his paper. If he wants to use another source, he must use quotation marks to show that the words belong to someone else.
Hint: Does copying and pasting from the internet show that the student understands the topic?

Wrong answer.  This IS NOT Academic Integrity.  The student must use his own words in his paper. If he wants to use another source, he must use quotation marks to show that the words belong to someone else.
Hint: Does copying and pasting from the internet show that the student understands the topic?
Is this an example of academic integrity?
I’ve got a big calculus exam on Friday. Could you help me review these problems to make sure I understand?
Section 1.3

Wrong answer.  This IS Academic Integrity.  As long as your professor approves, there’s nothing wrong with working together to study before a test. Anyone can study, so this isn’t unfair to other students.
Hint: Is studying together before a test unfair to other students?

Correct answer!  This IS Academic Integrity.  As long as your professor approves, there’s nothing wrong with working together to study before a test.   Anyone can study, so this isn’t unfair to other students.
Hint: Is studying together before a test unfair to other students?
Is this an example of academic integrity?
Hey, last semester I wrote a paper about healthcare reform. Why don’t you just borrow some of my ideas?
Section 1.3

Correct answer!  This IS NOT Academic Integrity.  Students should produce their own original work. They should not recycle work or turn in the work done by other people.  If this student “borrows” some of his friend’s ideas, he is not creating his own work, and he is taking credit for someone else’s effort.
Hint: Would one student be receiving credit for another student’s efforts?

Wrong answer.  This IS NOT Academic Integrity.  Students should produce their own original work. They should not recycle work or turn in the work done by other people.  If this student “borrows” some of his friend’s ideas, he is not creating his own work, and he is taking credit for someone else’s effort.
Hint: Would one student be receiving credit for another student’s efforts?
Is this an example of academic integrity?
Just distract the professor long enough for me to look at my phone. I took a picture of the formulas we need to know.
Section 1.3

Correct answer!  This IS NOT Academic Integrity.  When taking an exam, students should only bring materials approved by the professor.  By sneaking in a picture of the formulas, this student is not learning what he needs to succeed in his career.
Hint: Does sneaking in a picture of the formulas harm the student in any way?

Wrong answer.  This IS NOT Academic Integrity.  When taking an exam, students should only bring materials approved by the professor.  By sneaking in a picture of the formulas, this student is not learning what he needs to succeed in his career.
Hint: Does sneaking in a picture of the formulas harm the student in any way?
Is this an example of academic integrity?
The whole exam is online. Wouldn’t it be easier if we just did it together?
Section 1.3
Correct answer!  This IS NOT Academic Integrity.  An online exam is just like an in-class exam. The students shouldn’t receive any help not approved by the professor.
Hint: If the exam was taken in class, would the students be allowed to take it together?
Wrong answer.  This IS NOT Academic Integrity.  An online exam is just like an in-class exam. The students shouldn’t receive any help not approved by the professor.
Hint: If the exam was taken in class, would the students be allowed to take it together?
Is this an example of academic integrity?
I’m going to see one of the JagPAL tutors to get some help in my chemistry class.
Section 1.3
Wrong answer.  This IS Academic Integrity.  As long as your professor approves, the JagPAL tutors are a great way to get extra help in your tough classes.
Hint: Will studying with a JagPAL prevent the student from learning what she needs to do well in her classes and career?
Correct answer!  This IS Academic Integrity.  As long as your professor approves, the JagPAL tutors are a great way to get extra help in your tough classes.
Hint: Will studying with a JagPAL prevent the student from learning what she needs to do well in her classes and career?
Congratulations! You have completed Part 1 of the Academic Integrity Workshop.
To finish the workshop and receive certification, return to the USAOnline project page and select Academic Integrity Workshop, Part 2.
